Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Applications of Stochastic Analysis to Models of Multi-Agent Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent advances in continuous-time contract theory, some of which have come out from the prior work of the investigators, as well as advances in equilibrium theory and in modeling liquidity, are applied in order to develop more realistic models of interactions of multiple economic agents. In particular, optimal design of joint ventures between two firms is addressed, that is, the optimal time to enter/exit a project, the optimal effort each should invest in it, and how they should share the profits/losses, thus extending the classical real options theory to the case of two agents. New models for finding optimal compensation to managers are developed, in which the manager may have better information than the investors, and in which the investors may acquire better information at a cost. Global properties of prices formed in equilibrium of financial markets with many agents are analyzed, in order to study what factors influence the volatility and the risk premium of the stock market. In addition, the investigators model how prices locally evolve due to changes in liquidity, for example in the presence of fast high-frequency traders. Finally, in a model of a market with many interacting agents, the project explores how the average number of defaults and average loss evolve in the limit when the number of agents grows.

This project is particularly timely given that one of the reasons for the recent crisis in financial markets is the way traders and managers have been compensated. It will help provide insight into what types of compensation schemes are optimal for the parties involved and for the society in general. Another issue that needs better understanding if a similar crisis is to be prevented in the future, is how the markets evolve due to the interaction of many agents, and how lack of liquidity influences the behavior of the market participants and the prices. In particular, this research sheds light on the formation of asset prices, on portfolio strategies, and on the frequency of defaults that can be expected in markets with many agents, as well as how prices are formed in markets with varying degrees of liquidity. Thus, the results of the project will shed light on which issues to focus on when regulating compensation in financial markets and regulating the financial industry in general.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have performed research  on the following topics:

- 1.  Further developing continuous-time contract theory, with applications to optimal compensation of managers. We also published a book on this topic.

- 2. Equilibrium prices  in financial markets with heterogeneous agents.

 - 3. New Stochastic Differential Equations models for average number of defaults and average loss in markets with many agents.

Intellectual merit.  A lot of existing theory in Financial Mathematics
considers the problems of finding the optimal strategy for a single
entity -- an investor, a firm, a manager. While interaction of two
or more agents is sometimes considered, the models are usually either very stylized or untractable. We have advanced further the scope of the continuous-time contract theory, and developed more realistic models of interactions of multiple economic agents. We have developed new models for finding optimal compensation to managers: (i) a model in which the manager may have better information than the investors (ii) a model in which the manager influences both the return and the risk of a project  (iii) a model in which the manager has behavioral risk preferences  (iv) a model in which the manager may hedge the riks of compensation payments.
 Our theoretical work on equilibrium in markets in which agents have heterogeneous risk preferences helps explain empirically observed phenomena.
 We developed a new theory of delegated investment that addresses the behavior of financial markets in which most of the trade is done by portfolio managers.
We developed a new "contagion" model for defualt risk of a large number of firms.

Broader Impacts. Our research on contract theory is of particular interest given that one of the reasons for the 2008 crisis in financial markets is the way traders and managers have been compensated. Another issue that needs better understanding if we are to prevent similar crisis in the future, is how the markets evolve due to the interaction of many agents.  Our findings also shed light on how prices are formed in financial markets; how default risk spreads in the times of crisis; and which type of compensation schemes are optimal for the parties involved and the society in general. Thus, they may help regulators decide on which issues to focus on when regulating compensation and regulating financial markets and the financial industry.

Some of the results obtained through this research have been incorporated into the courses the PI teaches. The project involved several Ph.D students and a postdoc, from Social Sciences and from Applied Mathematics, who learned about state-of-the-art methods for studying optimal compensation issues, and who have started applying those methods in solving new problems. They also learned about  models for analyzing price formation in financial markets, which will be useful whether they start an academic career related to finance, or go on to work in the financial industry or  government regulatory institutions.
 Together with my co-author, I have also finalized and published a book on continuous-time contract theory. The techniques we have developed in our work, and also described in the book, have been used by economists to solve optimal contracting problems.

Finally, the PI has been and will remain active in organization of conferences related to these topics.
